questions.question: What is the difference between a tuple and a list in Python?
options: Tuples are immutable and lists are mutable
Tuples are mutable and lists are immutable
Tuples are faster than lists
Tuples can contain elements of different types, while lists cannot

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'yield' keyword in Python?
options: To stop the execution of a function and return a value to the caller
To define a generator function that returns an iterator
To create a new instance of a class
To define a class method that can be called without creating an object

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'lambda' keyword in Python?
options: To define a class method that can be called without creating an object
To create a new instance of a class
To define a generator function that returns an iterator
To define an anonymous function

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'try-except' block in Python?
options: To stop the execution of a function and return a value to the caller
To define a generator function that returns an iterator
To handle exceptions and prevent the program from crashing
To define a class method that can be called without creating an object

questions.question: What is the difference between 'is' and '==' in Python?
options: 'is' checks if two objects are the same object in memory, while '==' checks if they have the same values
'==' checks if two objects are the same object in memory, while 'is' checks if they have the same values
'is' is used to compare primitive data types, while '==' is used to compare objects
There is no difference - they are two ways of checking if two objects are equal

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'map' function in Python?
options: To apply a function to every element of an iterable and return a new iterable with the results
To convert an iterable into a list
To filter the elements of an iterable and return a new iterable with the results
To reverse the order of the elements in an iterable

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'super' keyword in Python?
options: To create a new instance of a class
To define a generator function that returns an iterator
